Award.AwardTitle: Refinement of Historical Variability and the Baseline for Hydroclimatic Conditions within the Walker Basin: A Multi-Elevational Dendrochronological and Ecohydrological Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hydroclimatic variability is an increasingly important aspect of water supply planning in arid and semi-arid regions of the United States and the world. Our understanding of past processes at relevant timescales (i.e. decadal to centennial) is often derived from high resolution palaeorecords such as tree rings. This research project will use tree-ring records to quantify wet and dry episodes within the Walker River watershed in western Nevada/eastern California. Along with the collection of long tree-ring chronologies that will stretch from the present back over 1000 years, this project will establish baseline conditions at multiple study sites with respect to climate and ecology. To capture tree-ring responses to individual hydroclimatic variables, such as summertime temperatures and wintertime precipitation, the researchers will target four tree species across a range of elevations as well as multiple topographic aspects. Baseline ecological surveys will be conducted at each study site to allow for comparison of conditions among a wide range of other surveyed locations across the Great Basin region. The researchers will use in-situ, free-air temperature sensors to better interpret microsite conditions relative to modeled and regional climate data. A climate monitoring station will be installed at high elevation in an isolated portion of the watershed, which will capture not only temperature and precipitation, but also solar radiation, wind patterns, and soil conditions. Both the ecological and sensory data will aid interpretation of palaeoclimate records, as existing data for most of the conifer zones in the watershed are limited to modeling products. A primary goal of this project is to reconstruct seasonal climate variables which would serve as inputs to water balance modeling over the last 1200 years, a time period which has seen tremendous variability based on previous tree-ring and lake sediment studies. Evaluation of watershed behavior during past time periods that exceed the envelope of our modern observations will aid water managers and users in decision making and planning as we move into an uncertain future. Records of past processes show how landscapes respond to variations in climatic and energy input, and regardless of the cause of future changes in conditions, it is critical to understand watershed dynamics in arid and semi-arid environments.

This research approach will bolster knowledge in tree-ring science, increase our understanding of climatic variability at the watershed scale, and clarify relationships between tree-ring records and water budgets. Reconstruction results from the project will be of immediate use to scientists, water managers, and water users within the Walker Basin and adjacent watersheds. Climatic and ecological data acquired as a result of the project's surveys and installations will be available to a wide range of public users, with sensor data provided in real-time. By bringing together Federal, University, and Community College researchers, this project provides a unique opportunity for collaboration and outreach across diverse levels. Educational opportunities will be provided to graduate, undergraduate, and Community College students, who will be able to participate in field and laboratory work as well as scientific conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Walker River hydrologic system in western Nevada and eastern California has long been a center of water supply controversy and debate. This project was focused on an area of the basin where old trees are present, but very little climate and ecological information was available.

Vegetation was surveyed at a number of locations, and tree-ring samples, either as increment cores or as stem cross sections, were obtained from conifer species, including pinyon pine, limber pine, and western juniper. A weather station was built in the center of the study area, and a number of temperature sensors (iButtons) were distributed over the landscape to capture topographic influences on local microclimate.

The weather station measures air temperature, precipitation, solar radiation, wind patterns, and soil conditions at 2600 m elevation. A controllable web camera on the station takes hourly high-resolution snapshots of the landscape, including snow conditions. Station data are freely available on the web by visiting the project website, http://sensor.nevada.edu/WalkerBasinHydro/

Thanks to this project, a new system was designed for measuring snow water equivalent in remote mountain environments. A patent is now pending for this sensor, which consists of an aluminum platform about 1.3 m² in size, with a  is a 0.5-m diameter weighing plate in the center.

Changes in air temperature across the watershed were measured in relation to time of day, elevation, and aspect, allowing an improvement in models used to extrapolate weather records from actual instruments to entire mountains. One of these products is PRISM, which consists of monthly, yearly, and single-event temperature and precipitation for the United States. Using observations from this project, corrections were made to the way in which PRISM calculates values in western mountain landscapes.

Old trees were sampled on north- and south-facing slopes over a range of elevations (from 1975 to 3123 m). A live pinyon pine was dated to more than 1200 years in age, greatly extending the maximum age of 900 years previously reported for this Great Basin species. Within the study area, management practices have been based on a maximum age of ~500 years for pinyon-juniper woodlands, which is obviously much less than what actually exists on the ground. Tree-ring measurements developed by the project are currently being used by the PI to reconstruct hydroclimatic variability in the watershed, which will benefit water resource management.

Several graduate and undergraduate students supported by the project were mentored by the principal investigators and gained valuable experience in field and laboratory research. The co-PI, S. Strachan, used the project to complete his Ph.D. in Geography with a Minor in Business Administration.

During the project, the PI organized an international conference at the University of Nevada, Reno in collaboration with the Mountain Research Initiative, University of Bern, Switzerland. The four-day meeting, entitled "Global Fair and Workshop on Long-Term Observatories of Mountain Social-Ecological Systems", attracted 180 participants, about half of them from outside the USA. The meeting received media attention and generated excellent discussions and reflections on how to best develop, install, utilize, and maintain mountain observatories.

All sensor data, vegetation surveys, and tree-ring records developed under this project will be provided to public-domain repositories, thereby improving future climate, ecology, and forestry research. In addition, open-source software tools for the R numerical software were developed and made available in the public domain.
